title: Performance Management – Ultra Detailed Revision Edition
overview: Performance Management (20% of Part 1) is not just calculation—it is diagnostic analysis. It answers: Did we perform as expected? If not, why? Who is responsible? What behavior will this measurement system encourage? It covers the full spectrum from Variance Analysis (Static vs Flexible budgets, Mix/Yield, Sales variances) to Responsibility Accounting (ROI, RI, EVA, Transfer Pricing) and non-financial measures (Balanced Scorecard, Cost of Quality). The goal is to align behavior with strategy, prevent suboptimization, ensure long-term value creation, and understand the trade-offs between different performance metrics.
bulletNotes: Flex Your Budget: Always compare Actual Results to a Flexible Budget (adjusted for actual volume), never the Static Budget.
Variance Hierarchy: Total Variance = Sales Volume Variance (Quantity) + Flexible Budget Variance (Price/Efficiency).
Material Price Variance is based on Quantity PURCHASED (Procurement responsibility); Usage on Quantity USED (Production responsibility).
Fixed Overhead Volume Variance is unique: It measures CAPACITY utilization (Over/Under absorption), not spending control.
ROI Trap: Managers may reject profitable projects (e.g., 15% return) if they lower their current high ROI (e.g., 20%). This is Suboptimization.
Residual Income (RI) Fix: Measures absolute dollar value added above cost of capital. Aligns with shareholder value.
Transfer Pricing: Minimum Price = Variable Cost + Opportunity Cost (Lost Contribution Margin).
Balanced Scorecard: Adds Leading Indicators (Customer, Process, Learning) to Lagging Financial Indicators.
Cost of Quality: Investing in Conformance (Prevention/Appraisal) drastically reduces Non-Conformance (Failure) costs.
Sales Volume Variance uses Contribution Margin, not Selling Price.
Economic View: A favorable variance isn't always 'good' (e.g., cheap materials causing rework).
EVA refines RI by using NOPAT and Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC).
shortNotes: Think Economically: Favorable variances aren't always 'good' (e.g., cheap materials causing rework). Master the 'AQ × AP | AQ × SP | SQ × SP' column method. Understand that Performance Measures drive Behavior—be able to predict how a manager will act under ROI vs RI. Variance analysis is for control, not punishment. For transfer pricing, always consider opportunity cost based on capacity utilization. The Balanced Scorecard links non-financial leading indicators to financial lagging indicators through a strategy map.

concepts.title: 1. Philosophy & Budgeting Framework
concepts.content:
The Philosophy of Performance Management

Performance management answers critical diagnostic questions: "Did we perform as expected? Why or why not? Who is responsible for the deviation? What behavior will this measurement system encourage?" It is fundamentally about control, feedback, and continuous improvement.

Static vs Flexible Budget (The Foundation)

Static Budget (Master Budget): Prepared at the beginning of the period based on planned output. It does NOT adjust for actual activity levels. Used for planning and initial resource allocation.

Flexible Budget: A budget that adjusts to the actual output level using standard costs per unit. It answers: "What should our costs have been for the actual volume we achieved?" Used for performance evaluation.

Why This Matters: If actual sales volume increases, total variable costs naturally increase. Comparing actual costs to the original static budget would incorrectly suggest overspending. We must compare Actual Results to the Flexible Budget to isolate efficiency and price effects from volume effects.

The Three-Budget Framework:

  1. Static Budget: Based on planned volume.
  2. Flexible Budget: Based on actual volume using standard costs.
  3. Actual Results: Real results achieved.

concepts.title: 2. Variance Hierarchy & Sales Variances
concepts.content:
The Big Picture: Variance Hierarchy

Total Operating Income Variance = Actual Operating Income – Static Budget Operating Income

This total variance is broken down into two primary components:

  1. Sales Volume Variance: (Flexible Budget Operating Income – Static Budget Operating Income). The difference due purely to selling a different quantity than planned.
  2. Flexible Budget Variance: (Actual Operating Income – Flexible Budget Operating Income). The difference due to price, cost, and efficiency factors.

Sales Variances (Revenue Side)

Sales Price Variance:

Sales Price Variance = (Actual Selling Price – Standard Selling Price) × Actual Units Sold

  • Measures the impact of charging a different price than budgeted.
  • Responsibility: Typically Sales/Marketing Manager.
  • Favorable: Actual price > Standard price.

Sales Volume Variance:

Sales Volume Variance = (Actual Units Sold – Budgeted Units Sold) × Standard Contribution Margin per Unit

  • Crucial: Uses Contribution Margin, NOT Selling Price. Why? Because fixed costs do not change with volume in the short run. The profit impact of selling one more unit is its contribution margin.
  • Measures the impact of selling a different quantity than budgeted.
  • Responsibility: Often shared between Marketing (demand generation) and Production (capacity constraints).

Sales Mix and Quantity Variances (Multi-Product Firms):

  • Sales Mix Variance: Measures the impact of selling a different proportion of products than planned. (Actual Mix % – Budgeted Mix %) × Actual Total Units × Budgeted CM per Unit
  • Sales Quantity Variance: Measures the impact of selling a different total quantity than planned, assuming the budgeted mix. (Actual Total Units – Budgeted Total Units) × Budgeted Mix % × Budgeted CM per Unit
  • Together: Sales Volume Variance = Sales Mix Variance + Sales Quantity Variance.

concepts.title: 3. Direct Material & Labor Variances
concepts.content:
The 3-Column Method (Master This!)

This framework works for all variable cost variances.

Column 1
Actual		Column 2
Flexible (AQ × SP)		Column 3
Standard (SQ × SP)
Actual Quantity × Actual Price
(AQ × AP)		Actual Quantity × Standard Price
(AQ × SP)		Standard Quantity Allowed × Standard Price
(SQ × SP)
← Price/Rate Variance →
Column 1 – Column 2		← Usage/Efficiency Variance →
Column 2 – Column 3

Standard Quantity Allowed (SQ): Actual Output × Standard Input per Unit. This is the amount that should have been used for the actual production achieved.

Direct Materials Variances

Materials Price Variance (MPV):

MPV = (AP – SP) × AQ Purchased or using the column method: (AQ×AP) – (AQ×SP)

  • Critical Trap: Use Quantity PURCHASED (not used) for price variance. Purchasing Manager controls price at the point of purchase. Using quantity used would mix timing differences.
  • Responsibility: Purchasing Manager.

Materials Usage (Quantity) Variance (MUV):

MUV = (AQ Used – SQ Allowed) × SP or using the column method: (AQ×SP) – (SQ×SP)

  • Uses quantity USED in production.
  • Measures efficiency of material usage (waste, scrap, yields).
  • Responsibility: Production Manager.

Direct Labor Variances

Labor Rate Variance (LRV):

LRV = (AR – SR) × Actual Hours Worked or (AH×AR) – (AH×SR)

  • Means paying workers at a different rate than standard (e.g., using more skilled labor).
  • Responsibility: HR/Hiring Manager or Production (if overtime caused higher rates).

Labor Efficiency Variance (LEV):

LEV = (AH – SH Allowed) × SR or (AH×SR) – (SH×SR)

  • Measures productivity: Did workers take more or less time than expected?
  • Responsibility: Production Supervisor.

concepts.title: 4. Manufacturing Overhead Variances
concepts.content:
Variable Overhead Variances

Variable overhead is driven by an activity base (e.g., direct labor hours, machine hours).

Variable Overhead Spending Variance:

Spending Variance = (Actual Rate – Standard Rate) × Actual Hours

  • Similar to labor rate variance. Measures difference between actual variable overhead rate and standard rate.
  • Caused by paying different prices for variable overhead items (indirect materials, utilities).

Variable Overhead Efficiency Variance:

Efficiency Variance = (Actual Hours – Standard Hours Allowed) × Standard Rate

  • Driven entirely by the efficiency of the activity base. If labor hours are higher than standard, variable overhead costs will also be higher, even if spending per hour was on target.
  • Responsibility: Same as labor efficiency (Production).

Fixed Overhead Variances (Conceptually Different)

Fixed costs do not change with activity in the short run. Variance analysis focuses on spending control and capacity utilization.

Key Definitions:

  • Budgeted Fixed Overhead: The planned lump-sum amount.
  • Applied Fixed Overhead: Standard Hours Allowed × Predetermined Fixed Overhead Rate. (Rate = Budgeted Fixed OH / Budgeted Capacity)

Fixed Overhead Spending (Budget) Variance:

Spending Variance = Actual Fixed OH – Budgeted Fixed OH

  • Measures whether the company spent more or less than planned on fixed costs (e.g., rent, salaries).
  • Simple cost control measure.

Fixed Overhead Volume Variance:

Volume Variance = Budgeted Fixed OH – Applied Fixed OH

  • This variance is unique to fixed overhead. It exists because fixed overhead is applied to products based on standard hours.
  • If Actual Output > Budgeted Output → Applied > Budgeted → Favorable Volume Variance (over-absorption).
  • If Actual Output < Budgeted Output → Applied < Budgeted → Unfavorable Volume Variance (under-absorption).
  • Interpretation: It measures capacity utilization, not spending efficiency. An unfavorable volume variance means the company did not use its capacity as planned, leaving idle capacity.

4-Way and 3-Way Overhead Analysis: The exam may ask to combine these. Know that the 3-way combines spending variances (Variable Spending + Fixed Spending) and separates efficiency and volume.

concepts.title: 5. Advanced Variance Analysis & Interpretation
concepts.content:
Trade-Offs & Economic Interpretation

A favorable variance is not automatically 'good' performance. Always analyze the net impact and potential trade-offs:

  • Favorable Material Price + Unfavorable Material Usage: Bought cheaper, lower-quality materials that caused more scrap.
  • Favorable Labor Efficiency + Unfavorable Labor Rate: Used more skilled (expensive) workers who got the job done faster.
  • Favorable Material Usage + Unfavorable Labor Efficiency: Used less material but spent more time processing (maybe due to material hardness).

When to Investigate Variances: Not every variance merits investigation. Criteria include:

  • Materiality: Size of variance (absolute or percentage).
  • Recurrence: Consistent pattern may indicate systemic issue.
  • Controllability: Can the responsible manager actually influence it?
  • Strategic Impact: Does it affect quality, customer satisfaction, or long-term goals?

Mix and Yield Variances (Manufacturing)

For processes where materials are combined:

  • Materials Mix Variance: Measures the cost impact of using a different proportion of inputs than standard. (Actual Mix % – Standard Mix %) × Actual Total Quantity × Standard Price
  • Materials Yield Variance: Measures the cost impact of getting more or less output from the total quantity of inputs. (Actual Yield – Standard Yield from Actual Input) × Standard Cost per Unit of Output

concepts.title: 6. Responsibility Accounting (ROI vs RI vs EVA)
concepts.content:
Responsibility Centers

Organizational units are classified by what managers control:

  • Cost Center: Manager controls costs only (e.g., maintenance department, production line). Evaluated by variance analysis, cost per unit.
  • Revenue Center: Manager controls revenue only (e.g., sales department). Evaluated by sales targets, market share.
  • Profit Center: Manager controls both revenues and costs (e.g., product line). Evaluated by contribution margin, segment margin.
  • Investment Center: Manager controls revenues, costs, and invested capital (e.g., subsidiary, division). Evaluated by ROI, RI, EVA.

Return on Investment (ROI)

ROI = Operating Income / Average Invested Capital

DuPont Analysis (Expanded ROI):

ROI = (Operating Income / Sales) × (Sales / Average Invested Capital)
ROI = Profit Margin × Asset Turnover

  • Profit Margin: Measures profitability per dollar of sales.
  • Asset Turnover: Measures efficiency of using assets to generate sales.

The ROI Trap (Suboptimization): A manager with a high ROI (e.g., 20%) may reject a project that earns 15% (above the company's 10% cost of capital) because it would lower the division's average ROI. This is rational for the manager but harmful to the company. ROI can encourage short-term focus and underinvestment.

Residual Income (RI)

RI = Operating Income – (Invested Capital × Required Minimum Rate of Return)

  • Measures absolute dollar value created above a minimum threshold.
  • The Fix: If a project's RI is positive, it increases the manager's performance measure. This aligns with shareholder value creation and solves the underinvestment problem.
  • Disadvantage: Can't easily compare different-sized divisions (larger divisions tend to have higher RI).

Economic Value Added (EVA)

A refined version of RI, trademarked by Stern Stewart & Co.

EVA = NOPAT – (Capital × Weighted Average Cost of Capital)

  • NOPAT: Net Operating Profit After Tax (adjusted to remove accounting distortions).
  • Capital: Total capital employed (adjusted to reflect economic capital).
  • Adjustments: Add back R&D, goodwill, etc., to reflect economic reality.
  • Widely used for executive compensation and value-based management.

concepts.title: 7. Transfer Pricing
concepts.content:
Purpose of Transfer Pricing

Transfer prices are charged when one division sells goods or services to another division within the same company. The goals are:

  • Goal Congruence: Ensure divisional decisions benefit the company as a whole.
  • Autonomy: Allow divisional managers to operate independently.
  • Performance Evaluation: Fairly measure each division's profitability.
  • Tax Optimization: In multinational companies, shift income to lower-tax jurisdictions.

General Transfer Pricing Rule

Minimum Transfer Price = Variable Cost + Opportunity Cost

The opportunity cost depends on capacity utilization:

  • Excess Capacity (No outside demand): Opportunity Cost = $0. Minimum price = Variable Cost (usually variable manufacturing cost). Any price above variable cost contributes to covering fixed costs.
  • Full Capacity (Can sell all output externally): Opportunity Cost = Lost Contribution Margin from external sales. Minimum price = Variable Cost + Lost CM = Market Price.

Transfer Pricing Methods

  • Market-Based Price: Using the external market price. Best for goal congruence and autonomy when a competitive market exists. Provides unbiased performance evaluation.
  • Cost-Based Price: Using variable cost, full cost, or cost-plus.
    • Variable Cost: Simple, but selling division shows no profit, making it a cost center.
    • Full Cost: Includes allocated fixed costs. May pass on inefficiencies of selling division to buying division.
    • Cost-Plus: Adds a markup to provide profit to selling division.
  • Negotiated Price: Divisions bargain to set the price. Preserves autonomy but can lead to conflict and consume management time.

International Transfer Pricing: Must comply with arm's length principle (OECD guidelines) to avoid tax penalties. Companies often set prices to minimize global tax burden (e.g., set low price into high-tax country, high price into low-tax country).

concepts.title: 8. Balanced Scorecard & Strategic Performance Measurement
concepts.content:
The Balanced Scorecard (BSC) – Kaplan & Norton

The BSC translates strategy into operational objectives across four perspectives, balancing financial and non-financial measures, lagging and leading indicators.

  1. Financial Perspective: "How do we look to shareholders?"
    • Typical measures: ROI, EVA, Revenue Growth, Profitability.
    • Lagging indicators: Reflect results of past actions.
  2. Customer Perspective: "How do customers see us?"
    • Typical measures: Customer satisfaction, Market share, Customer retention, On-time delivery.
    • Focus on value proposition: Price, Quality, Service, Relationship.
  3. Internal Business Process Perspective: "What must we excel at?"
    • Typical measures: Cycle time, Defect rates, Productivity, Cost per unit.
    • Focus on processes that deliver customer value and financial results.
  4. Learning and Growth Perspective: "Can we continue to improve and create value?"
    • Typical measures: Employee training hours, Employee satisfaction, IT systems capability, Innovation rate.
    • Leading indicators: Drive future performance in other perspectives.

Strategy Map

A visual tool showing cause-and-effect relationships among the four perspectives:

Learning & Growth (Employee skills) → Internal Processes (Process improvements) → Customer (Satisfaction, Loyalty) → Financial (Revenue, Profit).

Critical Success Factors (CSFs)

Key areas where performance must be excellent to achieve strategic goals. The BSC identifies CSFs and measures them with Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).

concepts.title: 9. Cost of Quality (COQ)
concepts.content:
The Four Categories of Quality Costs

Understanding where quality costs occur helps prioritize investment in prevention.

  • Prevention Costs (Conformance): Costs incurred to prevent defects from occurring.
    • Examples: Quality training, design reviews, process control, supplier certification.
    • Best investment – proactive.
  • Appraisal Costs (Conformance): Costs incurred to detect defects before products reach customers.
    • Examples: Inspection, testing, quality audits.
    • Necessary but adds no value – just identifies problems.
  • Internal Failure Costs (Non-Conformance): Costs incurred when defects are discovered before shipment.
    • Examples: Scrap, rework, downtime, retesting.
    • Waste of resources.
  • External Failure Costs (Non-Conformance): Costs incurred when defects reach customers.
    • Examples: Warranty claims, returns, repairs, lost sales, brand damage.
    • Most expensive – can destroy customer trust.

Key Insight

There is a trade-off: Investing in Prevention and Appraisal (conformance costs) dramatically reduces Internal and External Failure (non-conformance costs). The optimal quality level is where total quality costs are minimized, often achieved by spending more upfront to prevent defects.

Quality of Conformance: Degree to which a product meets specifications.

Quality of Design: How well the product is designed (features, performance).

concepts.title: 10. Behavioral & Ethical Issues in Performance Management
concepts.content:
Behavioral Implications of Performance Measures

Performance measures drive behavior—sometimes dysfunctional behavior:

  • Suboptimization: Managers focus on their own division's metrics at the expense of overall company goals. Example: Transfer pricing disputes that harm overall profit.
  • Short-Termism (Myopia): Managers cut R&D, maintenance, or training to boost current period profits (common with annual bonus tied to ROI).
  • Gaming the System: Manipulating timing of sales or expenses to hit targets (e.g., channel stuffing, delaying necessary maintenance).
  • Budgetary Slack: Building excessive cushion into budgets to make targets easier to achieve.
  • Risk Aversion: Avoiding profitable but risky projects to ensure stable performance metrics.

Goal Congruence

The performance measurement system must align managers' personal incentives with the company's best interests. This requires:

  • Choosing metrics that reflect long-term value creation (RI/EVA better than ROI).
  • Balancing financial and non-financial measures (Balanced Scorecard).
  • Including both leading and lagging indicators.
  • Regular review of unintended consequences.

Ethical Considerations

Managers face pressure to meet targets. Ethical pitfalls include:

  • Misreporting actual results.
  • Improperly classifying expenses as capital items.
  • Delaying necessary write-offs.
  • Pressure on subordinates to cut corners on quality or safety.

IMA Statement of Ethical Professional Practice: Competence, Confidentiality, Integrity, Credibility. Managers must report information fairly and objectively.

mistakes: Using Budgeted Hours instead of Standard Hours Allowed for efficiency variances.
Using Quantity Used instead of Quantity Purchased for Material Price Variance.
Assuming Favorable Variance = Good Performance (ignore quality trade-offs).
Confusing Fixed OH Volume Variance with Spending Variance (Volume is about capacity).
Using Selling Price instead of Contribution Margin for Sales Volume Variance.
Ignoring Opportunity Cost in Transfer Pricing when at full capacity.
Rejecting a positive-NPV project because it lowers division ROI (suboptimization).
Classifying Inspection as Prevention (it is Appraisal).
Thinking all variances are controllable by the same manager (price vs usage have different owners).
Forgetting that Variable OH Efficiency Variance is driven by the efficiency of the activity base, not overhead spending.
Applying learning curve to all costs (only applies to labor-intensive processes).
Misinterpreting R-squared as correlation (R² is the square of correlation coefficient).

quiz.question: Which of the following best describes the 'Minimum Transfer Price' when the selling division has excess capacity?
quiz.explanation: With excess capacity, there is no opportunity cost (no lost sales). Thus, the minimum price is simply the Variable Cost.

quiz.question: A favorable Direct Material Price Variance coupled with an unfavorable Direct Material Usage Variance most likely indicates:
quiz.explanation: Buying cheap materials (Favorable Price) often leads to waste/scrap (Unfavorable Usage). This is a classic trade-off.

quiz.question: Why is Residual Income (RI) often preferred over Return on Investment (ROI) for performance evaluation?
options: It is a percentage, making comparison easier
It eliminates the suboptimization problem of underinvestment
It focuses solely on gross margin
It ignores the cost of capital
quiz.explanation: RI encourages managers to accept ANY project that earns more than the cost of capital, whereas ROI leads managers to reject profitable projects that might lower their average ROI.

quiz.question: Which of the four Balanced Scorecard perspectives is considered a 'Leading Indicator'?
quiz.explanation: Learning & Growth (training, systems) drives improvement in Process, which drives Customer, which drives Financial results. It is the foundation.

quiz.question: Fixed Overhead Volume Variance determines the difference between:
options: Actual Fixed Costs and Budgeted Fixed Costs
Budgeted Fixed Costs and Applied Fixed Costs
Actual Fixed Costs and Applied Fixed Costs
quiz.explanation: Volume Variance = Budgeted Fixed Overhead - Applied Fixed Overhead. It measures whether the company produced enough volume to validly 'absorb' the fixed costs.

essay.question: Evaluate the behavioral implications of using ROI as the sole performance metric for an investment center manager. Start by defining ROI, then discuss at least two specific dysfunctional behaviors it might encourage, and propose an alternative metric that could mitigate these issues.
essay.modelAnswer:
1. Definition: ROI (Return on Investment) = Operating Income / Invested Capital. It measures the return generated per dollar of investment.

2. Dysfunctional Behaviors:

  • Underinvestment (Suboptimization): A manager with a high current ROI (e.g., 20%) may reject a profitable project yielding 15% (above the company's 10% cost of capital) because it would mathematically lower their average 20% ROI. This hurts the company's total value.
  • Short-Termism: Managers may cut R&D, maintenance, or training costs to boost the numerator (Income) or delay asset purchases to reduce the denominator (Invested Capital), harming long-term viability.

3. Alternative Metric: Residual Income (RI) or EVA. RI = Income - (Capital × Cost of Capital). Since RI measures absolute dollar value added, the manager in the example above would accept the 15% project because it generates positive RI, aligning personal incentives with company shareholders.

summary: Performance Management (20%) is the diagnostic heart of Part 1. It requires moving beyond calculation to interpretation. Mastery involves understanding the 'Why' behind variances (Trade-offs), the 'Who' behind responsibility (Centers), and the 'How' of motivation (ROI vs RI). Success here means thinking like a CFO, not just a calculator.

test.question: An unfavorable labor efficiency variance may be caused by:
test.explanation: Poor material quality can slow production.

test.question: If market price exists, best transfer price is:
test.explanation: Market price promotes goal congruence.

test.question: Which perspective asks: 'How do customers see us?'
test.explanation: Customer perspective evaluates customer satisfaction and retention.

test.question: If actual material cost equals standard cost, total material variance is:
test.explanation: No difference between actual and standard means zero variance.

test.question: Which variance is impacted by changes in capacity utilization?
test.explanation: Volume variance reflects capacity usage.

test.question: If variable cost per unit increases unexpectedly, which variance captures it?
test.explanation: Spending variance captures rate differences.

test.question: A manager evaluated using ROI may focus on:
test.explanation: ROI encourages short-term financial focus.

test.question: Prevention costs are intended to:
test.explanation: Prevention stops defects before they occur.

test.question: A favorable material usage variance means:
test.explanation: Using fewer inputs than standard reduces cost.

test.question: If a division increases assets but income remains constant, ROI will:
test.explanation: Higher denominator reduces ROI.

test.question: Which cost is most damaging to brand reputation?
test.explanation: External failures affect customers directly.

test.question: Transfer pricing should ideally achieve:
test.explanation: Transfer pricing should align divisional goals with company goals.

test.question: Asset turnover measures:
test.explanation: Asset turnover reflects revenue generated per dollar of assets.

test.question: If actual hours are less than standard hours allowed, efficiency variance is:
test.explanation: Using fewer hours indicates efficiency.

test.question: Which responsibility center controls assets and profits?
test.explanation: Investment centers control revenue, cost, and assets.

test.question: If a project return exceeds hurdle rate but is below current ROI, ROI evaluation may cause:
test.explanation: ROI system may reject profitable project.

test.question: Cycle time reduction falls under:
test.explanation: Internal process focuses on operational efficiency.

test.question: If standard hours allowed equal actual hours, efficiency variance is:
test.explanation: No difference results in zero variance.

test.question: Which metric is most aligned with shareholder wealth creation?
test.explanation: EVA measures economic profit after cost of capital.

test.question: If actual material price equals standard price but more quantity is used, which variance is affected?
test.explanation: If price is equal but more material is used, only usage variance is affected.

test.question: A favorable fixed overhead volume variance indicates:
options: Actual fixed costs were lower than budgeted
test.explanation: Producing more than expected spreads fixed costs more efficiently.

test.question: Which performance measure focuses on dollar value created above cost of capital?
test.explanation: Residual Income measures profit after capital charge.

test.question: If a company wants to improve long-term innovation, it should emphasize which BSC perspective?
test.explanation: Learning & Growth supports innovation and capability development.

test.question: A negotiated transfer price may lead to:
test.explanation: Negotiations can create disputes between divisions.

test.question: If actual sales are lower than budgeted, sales volume variance is:
test.explanation: Lower sales reduce contribution margin.

test.question: Which variance reflects differences in wage rates paid?
test.explanation: Labor Rate Variance captures wage rate differences.

test.question: Which cost would most likely be reduced by increasing prevention activities?
test.explanation: Prevention reduces costly external failures.

test.question: If actual variable overhead rate exceeds standard rate, variance is:
test.explanation: Higher actual rate increases cost.

test.question: Which measure combines margin and asset efficiency?
test.explanation: DuPont decomposes ROI into margin and turnover.

test.question: If material usage variance is unfavorable, possible cause is:
test.explanation: Poor quality materials can increase waste.

test.question: Which BSC perspective directly drives customer satisfaction?
test.explanation: Improved internal processes improve customer experience.

test.question: If division ROI is 18% and new project ROI is 14% while hurdle rate is 10%, RI evaluation would:
test.explanation: Since 14% exceeds hurdle rate, RI increases.

test.question: Which cost occurs before defects happen?
test.explanation: Prevention costs stop defects before occurrence.

test.question: If actual hours exceed standard hours allowed, labor efficiency variance is:
test.explanation: Using more hours than standard increases cost.

test.question: Which variance is independent of cost spending?
test.explanation: Volume variance depends on production level, not spending.

test.question: EVA is considered superior because it:
test.explanation: EVA measures value created after cost of capital.

test.question: If asset turnover increases while margin stays constant, ROI will:
test.explanation: Higher turnover increases ROI.

test.question: A company operating below capacity should use which minimum transfer price?
test.explanation: Opportunity cost is zero at excess capacity.

test.question: Balanced Scorecard reduces risk of:
test.explanation: It balances financial and non-financial metrics.

test.question: If actual output equals denominator capacity, fixed volume variance is:
test.explanation: No under- or over-absorption occurs.

test.question: Which responsibility center has highest level of autonomy?
test.explanation: Investment centers control assets, revenue, and costs.

test.question: If prevention costs increase, total quality cost should:
test.explanation: Prevention reduces expensive failure costs.

test.question: If actual material price is lower but usage higher, net effect depends on:
test.explanation: Total material variance determines overall effect.

test.question: The primary objective of performance management systems is to:
options: Align managerial behavior with organizational strategy
test.explanation: Effective systems align incentives with long-term corporate goals.
